Package edu.uky.cs.nil.sabre.ptree

Class ProgressionTree

java.lang.Object
edu.uky.cs.nil.sabre.ptree.ProgressionTree
All Implemented Interfaces:
Serializable
public class ProgressionTree extends Object implements Serializable
A progression search space is a large table that stores the data for each node of a progression tree search through the space of states. States are not stored as objects to avoid excessive allocation on the heap during search; rather, data for each state is stored in a big array and each node is identified by an ID number. Most methods have a state ID number as a parameter.

A node can be thought of as an event/state pair, meaning each node has an event associated with it and can also be treated like a state. The event is the event that occurred immediately before the state. If the event is an action, it means the state is the state that results from applying the acton's effect to the previous state. If the event is a trigger, it means some trigger applied in the previous state and this state is the result. A node which is an initial state node has no associated event, so getEvent(long) will return null.

The node with ID number 0 is always the state that was used to initialize this tree. Node that initialize(State) may return a value other than 0 if triggers apply in that state, in which case the method will return the ID number of the node after all triggers have been applied.

Every node is associated with a character. Node 0 and its descendants are associated with the author, and getCharacter(long) will return null for those nodes. Every other node is reached by requesting the beliefs of some character in some state, and the resulting node and its descendants will be associated with that character. For example, if you call getBeliefs(long, Character) with node ID 0 and the first character from a problem, you will get the state that character believes the initial state to be.

To save memory (and the time required to allocate new memory), nodes do not store the value of each fluent, but rather the sequence of events that led to that state; the value of each fluent can then be derived from looking as the effects of each event starting from the most recent. This means that nodes take up little memory but methods like getValue(long, CompiledFluent) are relatively expensive.

Yes, I know this is a single class with 1500+ lines of code. Fight me, you cowards. It is good code, perhaps even beautiful in its way.

Author:
Stephen G. Ware

  • Constructor Details

    • ProgressionTree

      public ProgressionTree(CompiledProblem problem, EventTree<CompiledTrigger> triggers, long chunkSize, MemoryBudget budget)
      Constructs a new progression state space for a given problem with a given chunk size and memory budget for its big array.
      Parameters:
      problem - the problem whose search space this table will store
      triggers - an event tree of all triggers in the problem
      chunkSize - the chunk size in bytes for that big array that data will be stored in
      budget - the memory budget which limits the size of the big array that data will be stored in

    • ProgressionTree

      public ProgressionTree(CompiledProblem problem, EventTree<CompiledTrigger> triggers)
      Constructs a new progression state space for a given problem with a default chunk size and unlimited memory budget for its big array.
      Parameters:
      problem - the problem whose search space this table will store
      triggers - an event tree of all triggers in the problem

      Returns:

      Writes data for each node in the space to a writer. This method is generally used for debugging purposes.
      Parameters:
      writer - the write to which data will be sent
      Throws:
      IOException - if an exception occurs while writing to the writer

      Writes data for a node to a writer. This method is generally used for debugging purposes.
      Parameters:
      node - the ID number of the desired node
      writer - the writer to which data will be sent
      Throws:

    • size

      public long size()
      Returns the number of nodes in the state space.
      Returns:
      the number of nodes

    • initialize

      public long initialize(State initial)
      Initializes this state space by specifying the initial state that will form the root (node ID 0) of the tree; all other data will be erased.
      Parameters:
      initial - the state which will form the root of the tree
      Returns:
      the ID number of the node where the search should start, which will usually be 0, unless some triggers apply in given initial state, in which case the node ID returned will be the result after applying those triggers to node 0

    • getNextSolution

      public long getNextSolution()
      If any new solutions to the problem being modeled by this tree have been generated, this method returns the node ID of the a solution. A solution is a sequence of explained events starting at the root (node ID 0) that improves the author's utility. Once a solution has been returned by this method, it will not be returned again.
      Returns:
      the node ID of a solution which has been generated and has not yet been returned, or -1 if there are no solutions waiting to be returned

    • getRoot

      public long getRoot(long node)
      Returns the ID number of a node's root, which is found by going back into the past until the initial state is reached or an unforeseen update was made to the state via a dummy action. A tree can contain many roots. A root can be thought of as the starting place for a branch of the search.
      Parameters:
      node - the ID number of the node whose root is desired
      Returns:
      the ID number of the node's root

    • getCharacter

      public Character getCharacter(long node)
      Returns the character associated with this node, or null if the node is associated with the author. Descendants of node 0 are all author nodes (for which this method returns null), but every other node represents the beliefs of some character. This method returns the character whose beliefs this node represents.
      Parameters:
      node - the ID number of the node whose character is desired
      Returns:
      the character or null if this node is associated with the author

    • getEvent

      public CompiledEvent getEvent(long node)
      Returns the event that occurred immediately before the state represented by this node, or null if the node is an initial state node.
      Parameters:
      node - the ID number of the node whose event is requested
      Returns:
      the event, or null if the node is an initial state node

    • getAction

      public CompiledAction getAction(long node)
      Returns the most recent action that occurred before the state represented by this node, or null if the node is an initial state node. If triggers apply after an action, the event returned by getEvent(long) will be the last trigger. This method is a convenient way to back up past any number of triggers to get the most recent action that occurred.
      Parameters:
      node - the ID number of the node whose action is requested
      Returns:
      the action, or null if the node is an initial state node

    • getPlan

      public HeadPlan<CompiledAction> getPlan(long node)
      Returns the sequence of actions that have occurred since the root that led to the state represented by a given node.
      Parameters:
      node - the ID number of the node where the plan should stop
      Returns:
      the sequence of actions starting at the root and leading up to node

    • getPlan

      public HeadPlan<CompiledAction> getPlan(long start, long end)
      Returns the sequence of actions that have occurred between the given start and end nodes. This method will return null if the end node is not a descendant of the start node or if there is a root node between the start and end (i.e. some unexpected state update happened between the start and end).
      Parameters:
      start - the ID number of the node representing the state where the plan should start
      end - the ID number of the node representing the state where the plan should end
      Returns:
      the sequence of actions between the start and end (which will be empty if no actions have occurred between the nodes) or null if the state and end pair is somehow invalid

      Returns the value a logical expression would have when evaluated in a given state.
      Parameters:
      node - the ID number of the node representing the state in which the logical expression will be evaluated
      expression - the logical expression to be evaluated
      Returns:
      the result of evaluating the expression in that state

      public Value getUtility(long node)

      Returns:

    • getBefore

      public long getBefore(long node)
      Returns the ID number of the node immediately before a given node (i.e. the state before the node's event). If the node is an initial state node, the node's own ID will be returned.
      Parameters:
      node - the ID number of a node
      Returns:
      the ID number of the node immediately before the given node

    • getBeforeAction

      public long getBeforeAction(long node)
      Returns the ID number of the node immediately before the most recent non-dummy action (i.e. the state the most recent non-dummy action was taken in). If there have been no non-dummy actions since the initial state, this method will return the ID number of the initial state node. This method skips over dummy actions that represent belief updates, such the belief updates that occur before a surprise action.
      Parameters:
      node - the ID number of a node
      Returns:
      the ID number of the node immediately before the most recent non-dummy action, or the initial state node if there have been no such actions

    • getChildren

      public int getChildren(long node)
      Returns the number of child nodes that have been generated so far for a given node. Children nodes are generated using the getChild(long, CompiledEvent) method. The getAfter(long, CompiledAction) method also generates children, but may return a descendant if triggers apply after the action.
      Parameters:
      node - the ID number of a node
      Returns:
      the number of children the node currently has

    • getLastChild

      public long getLastChild(long node)
      Returns the ID number of the most recently generated child node of a given node. This method can be used as the first step in traversing the list of all children; after getting the last child, the second to last child can be gotten using getPreviousSibling(long), and so on. To extend the metaphor, this method returns the ID of the youngest child, and each child knows the ID of it's next older sibling. This method returns -1 if the node has no children.
      Parameters:
      node - the ID number of a node whose most recent child is desired
      Returns:
      the ID number of the most recently generated child node, or -1 if the node has no children

    • getPreviousSibling

      public long getPreviousSibling(long node)
      Returns the ID number of the child node of this node's parent that was generated immediately before the given node. In other words, this method returns a child's next older sibling. This method can be used as the second, third, etc. step in traversing the list of a node's children; the first step is getLastChild(long). This method returns -1 if the node has no sibling.
      Parameters:
      node - the ID number of a node whose older sibling is desired
      Returns:
      the ID number of the older sibling, or -1 if no such node exists

    • getAfter

      public long getAfter(long node, CompiledAction action)
      Returns the node that results from taking a given action in a given state and then applying any relevant triggers. If such a node has been generated before, this method will return it; otherwise this method creates a new node.
      Parameters:
      node - the ID number of a node
      action - the action to be taken in the state represented by the node
      Returns:
      the ID number of a node whose state is the state after taking that action in that state (and then applying any relevant triggers)

    • getChild

      public long getChild(long parent, CompiledEvent event)
      Returns the node that results when a given event occurs in a given state. The node returned will have the given event as its event and will represent the state after applying the event's effect to the state represented by given node. This method does not check whether the event's precondition is satisfied. If such a node has already been generated, it will be returned; otherwise this method will create a new node. The returned node is called a child of the given node, which is called the parent. A node's children, and its children's children, etc. are called descendants.
      Parameters:
      parent - the ID number of a node
      event - the event to be taken in the state represented by the node
      Returns:
      the ID number of the child node whose event will be the event and whose state will be the state after applying the event's effect

    • getAfterTriggers

      public long getAfterTriggers(long node)
      Returns the ID number of the node that represents the state after applying any relevant triggers to the given node. If no triggers apply, the same node is returned.
      Parameters:
      node - the ID number of a node
      Returns:
      the ID number of the node after applying any relevant triggers, or the same node if no triggers apply

    • getBeliefs

      public long getBeliefs(long node, Character character)
      Returns the ID number of a node that represents the beliefs of an character in a given state. If the character's beliefs have already been generated for the given node, the same result will be returned again; otherwise new nodes will be generated. Any triggers that apply in the character's beliefs will have already been applied---in other words, the node ID returned will always be the result of calling getAfterTriggers(long) on whatever new state is generated. If the character given is null and the node given is associated with the author (i.e. getCharacter(long) returns null for that node), this method returns the result of getAfterTriggers(long); otherwise this method returns -1 any time the character is null, because the model does not define what a character believes the author believes.

      Here is how beliefs are derived. If the node given is an initial state node, then consult the initial state to derive the character's beliefs. Otherwise:

      1. Let N be the node and C the character given as input to this method.
      2. Starting at N, back up to the state before N and get C's beliefs for that node. Call this node B.
      3. If the event associated with N is an action and C observes it:
        1. If the action's precondition is not met in B, then create a dummy action to update C's beliefs so they will believe the action's precondition is met. Update B to be the state after that dummy action.
        2. Update B to be the state after the action.
      4. If the event has any effects which directly modify C's beliefs, create dummy belief updates actions to update C's beliefs with those modifications. Update B to be the state after those dummy action.
      5. Update B to be the state after applying any relevant triggers.
      6. Return B.
      Parameters:
      node - the ID number of a node representing some state
      character - the character whose beliefs are desired, or null if the author's beliefs are desired
      Returns:
      the ID number of a node representing a state that is the beliefs of the given character in the given state, or -1 if the character given was null and the node given was not associated with the author

    • getLastTrunk

      public long getLastTrunk(long node)
      Returns the ID number of a node's most recently generated trunk. A trunk is the node from which a branch extends. This method can be used as the first step in traversing the list of all trunks; after getting the last trunk, the second to last trunk can be gotten using getPreviousTrunk(long, Character), and so on. This method returns -1 if the node has no trunks.
      Parameters:
      node - the ID number of the node whose last trunk is desired
      Returns:
      the ID number of the node's most recently generated trunk, or -1 if the node has no trunks

    • getPreviousTrunk

      public long getPreviousTrunk(long node, Character character)
      Returns the ID number of the trunk node for the same character's branch that was generated immediately before the given node. In other words, this method returns a branch's next oldest trunk (for some character). This method can be used as the second, third, etc. step in traversing the list of a node's trunks; the first step is getLastTrunk(long). This method returns -1 if the node has no next oldest trunk for that character.
      Parameters:
      node - the ID number of a node whose older trunk is desired
      character - the character for whom the trunk branches
      Returns:
      the ID number of the older trunk, or -1 if no such node exists

    • getBranch

      public long getBranch(long node, Character character)
      Returns the ID number of a node's branch for a given character. A branch is the state one of an action's consenting characters believes the world to be in after taking the most recent action. The node from which the branch extends is called the trunk. A branch exists for a given character if the character is a consenting character to the most recent action and if that character believes the action is possible. If the branch already exists, this method will return it. If the branch can be generated, this method will generate it. If the branch does not exist (because the character is not a consenting character or because they do not believe the action is possible) this method returns -1. If a branch exists, the node ID returned will be after after applying any relevant triggers.

      If the given character matches the character associated with the given node, the node returned will be the given node after applying triggers. In other words, the branch used to explain an action for a character in that character's own mind is the trunk. This also applies if the given node is associated with the author (getCharacter(long) returns null) and the given character is null.

      Branches are used to explain actions. An action is explained if a branch exists for each of its consenting characters and if each of those branches has an explanation for that branch's character. It is important to generate the branches for an action so that it can become explained. It is possible to obtain the same node ID by backing up to the state before the action, getting the character's beliefs, and taking the action, but it is important to use this method because it registers the branch as belonging to this trunk. This way, when the branch becomes explained, the trunk action will be notified that it has been explained for the branch character.

      Parameters:
      node - the ID number of the trunk node for which a branch is desired
      character - the character for whom the branch is desired
      Returns:
      the ID number of the branch node, or -1 if the branch does not exist

    • getBest

      public long getBest(long node)
      Returns the ID number of a node that is the best (i.e. increases utility the most) known explained descendant of a given node. An "explained descendant" means all of the actions between the given node and the descendant are explained. If there are no explained descendants, or if none have a higher utility than the given node, the node ID itself is returned.
      Parameters:
      node - the ID number of a node for whom a best explained descendant is desired
      Returns:
      the ID number of one of the node's best explained descendants, or the given node ID if no such descendant exists

    • getWorst

      public long getWorst(long node)
      Returns the ID number of a node that is the worst (i.e. decreases utility the most) known explained descendant of a given node. An "explained descendant" means all of the actions between the given node and the descendant are explained. If there are no explained descendants, or if none have a lower utility than the given node, the node ID itself is returned.
      Parameters:
      node - the ID number of a node for whom a worst explained descendant is desired
      Returns:
      the ID number of one of the node's worst explained descendants, or the given node ID if no such descendant exists

    • isExplained

      public boolean isExplained(long node)
      Checks whether a given node make sense, which means that for every consenting character of the the most recent action nodes have been generated that demonstrate the character can imagine a plan starting with that action which increases their utility.

      If the most recent action is a dummy action (which are used to impose unexpected belief updates), this method will return false, because an unexpected action cannot be explained.

      Parameters:
      node - the ID number of a node
      Returns:
      true if the most recent action makes sense for all its consenting characters, false otherwise

    • isExplained

      public boolean isExplained(long node, Character character)
      Checks whether a given node make sense for a given character, which means the character is a consenting character for the most recent action and node have been generated that demonstrate the character can imagine a plan starting with that action which increases their utility.
      Parameters:
      node - the ID number of a node
      character - a character from whom the node may be explained
      Returns:
      true if the character is a consenting character for the most recent action and the action makes sense for that character, false otherwise

    • getExplanation

      public long getExplanation(long node, Character character)
      Returns the ID number of a node representing the explanation of the most recent action for a given character. An explanation for an action for a character is the state after a plan the character believes is possible that starts with the action and increases the character's utility the most. If no explanation for this character has yet been generated this method returns -1.

      Note that an explanation is either the branch for the given character or one of its descendants. This means the state the node represents and the plan to get there may not actually be possible in the state represented by the given node; it only needs to be something the character believes is possible.

      Parameters:
      node - the ID number of a node for which an explanation of the most recent action is desired
      character - the character for whom the explanation is desired
      Returns:
      the ID number of a node that represents the state after executing a plan the character believes is possible that starts with the action and which they believe will increase their utility the most, or -1 if no such node has been generated

    • getGoal

      public Clause<Precondition> getGoal(long node)
      Returns a clause from the best known descendant of a given node that is sufficient to ensure the utility expression of the character associated with the node evaluates to their utility in that state. In other words, this method returns a clause the character wants to make true (if there is a way to improve their utility) or a clause which expresses why their utility is what it currently is in the given state.
      Parameters:
      node - the ID number of a node representing a state
      Returns:
      a clause that is true in the best known descendant state which is sufficient to explain the character's utility in that state

    • getSolution

      public Solution<CompiledAction> getSolution(long node)
      Returns a solution plan that starts at a given node and ends at the best known descendant that improves the utility of the character associated with the node. If there is no known way to improve utility from the given node, this method returns null.
      Parameters:
      node - the ID number of the node representing the state in which the solution should start
      Returns:
      a solution starting in the given state and leading to a state where the utility of the character associated with the node is improved, or null if no such solution has been generated

    • getSolution

      public Solution<CompiledAction> getSolution(long start, long end)
      Returns a solution plan that starts at a given node and passes through a second given node on the way to a descendant that most improves the the utility of the character associated with the nodes. If the second node is a descendant of the first that improves the character's utility, the solution will end there; otherwise, the solution will end in the state that explains the action associated with the second node, and as a result the solution will both include that action and pass through the state after that action. If the second node is not a descendant of the first, or if there is no solution which starts at the first node and passes through the second, this method returns null.
      Parameters:
      start - the ID number of the node representing the state in which the solution should start
      end - the ID number of a node representing a state which the solution should pass through
      Returns:
      a solution starting in the first given state and passing through the second, or null if no such solution exists
